concern:
I was very confused about what to major in after high school. But i searched a bit about computer science, it courses from what my future uni offers, asked for advice around, listened to people from yt IN cs and its jobs prospects, plus i started to like the field but have no experience in coding, so thats what i chose… 
   Did i make a good choice?


(I have good grades)
(I wont say i have practice in every maths courses cs offers but i like maths so thats that thing out of the way)
(Also please advice if I wont lose job opportunities as a Women in cs)

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm excited to listen and explore your thoughts, feelings, and concerns with you. Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind, and I'll be here to support you every step of the way.

Thanks for having me, I’m glad to be here to talk. I’ve been kinda stressing about whether I made the right choice picking computer science as my major, and I just want to figure out if I’m on the right track.

That's completely understandable. It's a big decision, and it's natural to have some doubts. Can you tell me more about what's been on your mind and what led you to choose computer science in the first place?

I guess I picked it because I did a lot of research and started to like the idea of working in tech, even though I don’t have any real experience yet. I’m just worried if I’m setting myself up for something I might struggle with or if I’ve made a mistake jumping into it.

So, like, do you think it’s okay to start a major like this without any background, or am I kinda setting myself up to fail? I mean, I’m willing to put in the work, but I just don’t know if I’m starting too far behind.

I can hear the effort you put into choosing computer science, and it's great that you're thinking about your decision and how to move forward. Many people start majors without prior experience and succeed by putting in the work, so it's possible for you to do the same. What do you think would help you feel more confident about your choice?

Honestly, I think having some kind of reassurance that I can catch up and not be totally lost would help a ton. Maybe like, knowing there are resources or ways to get a head start before I’m drowning in coursework—do you think there’s stuff I can do now to prep myself?

It sounds like you're eager to set yourself up for success, which is a really positive sign! There are definitely ways to prepare before diving into coursework—have you considered looking into online tutorials, introductory courses, or even connecting with upperclassmen or professors in the department? These could help you build a foundation and get a sense of what to expect. What do you think about exploring some of these options?

Yeah, I think that sounds like a good idea—looking into online tutorials or reaching out to people in the department could really help me get a feel for things. I just gotta figure out where to start with that, you know, like which resources are actually worth my time.

It's great that you're open to exploring these options and taking proactive steps to prepare yourself for your computer science major. Let's start by identifying some specific resources that could be a good fit for you. What areas within computer science are you most interested in, or do you have any specific goals in mind? This could help us narrow down which tutorials or courses might be most beneficial for you.

Honestly, I’m not super sure yet about specific areas since I’m so new to it, but I think stuff like coding basics or maybe something related to building apps sounds cool. I guess my main goal right now is just to get a grip on the fundamentals so I’m not totally lost when classes start—can we figure out some beginner-friendly stuff to focus on?

I'm glad to hear you're excited about exploring computer science and eager to start with the basics. Building a strong foundation in coding and app development sounds like a solid first step, and there are plenty of beginner-friendly resources available. How about we start with some popular platforms like Codecademy, Coursera, or edX? They offer introductory courses on coding basics and app development that could give you a solid head start. Would you be interested in checking those out?

Yeah, that sounds like a great starting point—I'm definitely down to check out Codecademy or Coursera to get a handle on the basics. I just hope I can keep up with it and not feel overwhelmed right off the bat, you know?

It's great that you're excited about exploring computer science and eager to start with the basics! Building a strong foundation in coding and app development is a solid first step, and there are plenty of beginner-friendly resources available. I'm glad you're open to checking out platforms like Codecademy or Coursera, which offer introductory courses on coding basics and app development. To help you stay on track and avoid feeling overwhelmed, let's break down your learning process into smaller, manageable tasks. How about setting aside a specific time each day or week to focus on your tutorials? You could also consider connecting with other beginners or online communities for support and motivation.

Hey, that sounds like a solid plan—setting aside specific times to work on tutorials could really help me stay consistent without getting stressed out. And yeah, connecting with other beginners online would be cool too, just to have people to bounce ideas off of or ask dumb questions without feeling judged.

It's great that you're open to setting aside dedicated time for tutorials and connecting with other beginners! This approach can help you stay focused and motivated. Let's consider creating a simple schedule to allocate time for tutorials each week. How many hours per week do you think you could realistically commit to practicing coding and app development? We can work together to create a plan that fits your schedule and helps you stay on track.

Hey, I’m glad we’re figuring this out together—I think I could realistically commit to maybe 5 or 6 hours a week to start with, since I’ve got other stuff going on too. Can we maybe set up a little schedule or something to split that time across a few days so it doesn’t feel like too much at once?
I'm really appreciative of your help in mapping this out. How about we break those 5 or 6 hours into a couple of shorter sessions across the week to keep it manageable?
Thanks for helping me think through this. I’m feeling good about starting with those 5 or 6 hours and splitting them up—maybe we can figure out which days work best for me to stay consistent?
